Thinking Lateral-ly
Science increasingly dominates every aspect of our lives, and many people now realise the importance of properly communicating new research to the public.

But let's be honest: for all the current enthusiasm around the communication of science, there aren't a lot of opportunities for young scientists and journalists to hone their writing skills in an editorial environment. Writing for a personal blog, while useful and rewarding, usually doesn't prepare you for a world of deadlines and editorial demands. Plus, at the end of the day, it's hard to put blogging on your resumé.

Lateral was designed to help fill this gap, bringing new voices and artists to the science media landscape - while also being a fantastic publication that will appeal to a wide audience, many of them also younger people. It will also pay all of its contributors, a rarity in the modern media landscape for younger writers and artists.The Young Australian Skeptics is proud to be bringing Lateral into the world as part of its mission to improve science communication to and from young people. Since 2008, the YAS has been publishing online articles on its eclectic group blog, has produced hundreds of hours of audio on two science and critical thinking-themed podcasts, The Pseudoscientists and Unfiltered Thoughts, and published the Skeptical Blog Anthology (2012), a collection of some of the Internet's best writing on science and skepticism.  And don't worry - we're not climate change deniers.
The Virtues of Crowdfunding
Why Do We Need All This Money?
Reimbursing our writers and artists for their time and effort is one of our top priorities – too many opportunities for new science communicators are unpaid, and we're bucking that trend. We're also designing Lateral with the fantastic team of young web developers over at DesignGel, who need to be paid. Our crowdfunding goal covers these costs of design, as well as providing funds for our first 6 months of articles and magazine content.
The cost of designing Lateral is $3,600, and 6 months of contributor payments, based on our planned publication frequency, is a little over $4,500. The headroom in our initial goal is to allow for the gradual expansion of the number of columns in the magazine, buffer against processing fees incurred during this campaign, and other, smaller initial website management costs. 

What Do You Get Out of It?
You'd think helping to bring a new publication to life from the depths of imagination would be reward enough ‒ but no, there's other stuff you can get if you support Lateral's creation. We thought long and hard about these perks, and realised that if you're willing to support a science communication magazine, you'd probably love to get involved somehow, rather than claim a low-quality, mass-produced t-shirt.
So, based on your contribution, you can sponsor an article or even an entire column for a whole year! Whoa. For those who want to get even more direct, you can commission an article about a topic of your choosing or choose an entire future month's theme. You'd be like a god. A science writing god. We're even throwing a launch party in Melbourne for those of you who want to meet us all in person: truly the greatest gift of all.
But What If...?
If we reach over 100% of our $10,000 goal, we've got some great ideas about how we would use such a generous outpouring of support, other than investing solely in future month-by-month operating costs of the magazine:
$15,000: If we reach 150% funding, we'll commission unique artwork for all of our articles, not just our featured themed articles. That's more gorgeous science-inspired artwork every month. Fantastic. 
$20,000: 200% funded means at least more 5 more articles per month, all with unique artwork! Damn.
$30,000: If we're lucky enough to receive 300% of our goal, we'll create a podcast companion based on the magazine, exploring the relationship between science and society in greater detail, in the way only audio can. This would launch Lateral into the multimedia sphere, supporting the development of the podcast and radio skills of emerging science communicators, not just their written and artistic abilities. 
  Risks? Challenges? As of the launch of this crowdfunding campaign, we've already planned the first month of articles and much of it is currently being written. There's a clear and on-target web design timeline as well, leading to the launch of Lateral on the 3rd of August. Everyone involved, from our editorial team, to our present and future contributors, to our designers, is super keen about the project and we're all working hard to make the magazine as polished and exciting as possible for you, our audience, to finally read and enjoy. 
Once the magazine has been initially funded, the only significant challenge to the future of Lateral will be maintaining a funding stream without commercial advertising, either through audience support via a platform such as Patreon, and/or ongoing partnerships with likeminded scientific organisations. This campaign gives us the breathing room required to settle on a model that keeps the magazine free to read, but allows us to continue to pay contributors for their time and effort. 
    Other Ways You Can Help If you can't pledge money towards our goal, that's totally fine, we understand. But helping get the word out there about Lateral is, in many ways, more helpful! Tell your friends, family, extremely-casual acquaintances: who knows, you might help them discover a new interest in science.
But most important, really, is to keep your eyes peeled for Lateral's grand launch in August! We've already got great stuff lined up for you to read and we can't wait to share it with you all.

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Anthony Colson, I am a father of a 5 year old son, and I am a resident of Houston, Tx, and I grew up wanting more of God. I attend Houston Worship Centre, in Houston, Tx, under Senior Pastor Randy Needham. I am a graduate of All Nations School of Ministry (www.allnations.cc), and I assist my Young Adults Pastor with 232, our young adults ministry, and with Revival Generation. I am beginning to write and blog online at www.anthonycolson.com.  am also a server at Tommy Bahama’s in The Woodlands.

This IndieGoGo campaign is the beginning of something that will have such a powerful impact. The publication of this book isn’t the end all, but the beginning of a powerful writing series that will show the power and beauty of salvation and a life lived with Jesus that I have yet found put to paper.

Through partnering with me in the publication of Experiencing Salvation, you will assist me in being able to minister the passionate love of God to those who have never heard it expressed as it is in this book. This is not another book talking about how to cope with despair until Jesus comes, but a beacon of hope and an answer to the personal cry of my heart on what it means to be truly saved and live passionately for one who gave His life for each one of us.  I write about the freedoms of living with an identity that took all the strength of God to create for every person who will ever live. This book ignites the heart, because in it I tell you, the reader, what it means to live as one so passionately loved, and how to live as one passionately loved by the Father of Jesus who is love.

Partner with me to get this book published.

What We Need & What You Get

I am asking for $5,500 USD (United States Dollars), to get the book published. This will go to all the aspects of publishing, cover design, marketing, and mainly book printing. Everything above that will go to printing more books, and provide me the ability to spend more time on the book campaign itself. The book is going to be published through High Bridge Books, and will be available in paperback and all the popular ebook formats.

 I want it to be easy to partner and help support this project. I really want to get this funded with a lot of people giving what may not seem like much and getting something that will powerfully help them in return.

So I have some giving levels.

$25 The “One for Anyone” package

  • A free signed copy upon book release
  • A free pdf version sampling of three chapters to whet your appetite
  • A free audio download of me ministering on the chapter “Joy of Repentance”

 

$100 The “Excited About This” package

  • Five (5) free signed copies upon book release, enough for the average family
  • A free pdf version of the complete book
  • Additional audio downloads, on the chapters, “So Much More,” “The Armor of God.”

$250 The “I Have Been Waiting This” package

  • Twelve (12) free signed copies upon book release, for the office or bible study
  • A free pdf version of the complete book
  • Additional audio download on the chapter “Born of Heaven”
  • Free video downloads consisting of a “Fire side chat,” on the various chapters and topics of the book, what went into writing, and how the book has changed me personally. Also, interviewed with the various editors, and some of the behind the scenes conversations that most people just do not get to have.

 

 

As far as delivery on the perks.

  • The Free PDFs will be available within 48 hours of donation. I don’t want you to be waiting for everything.
  • The books will be available on within ten days of my receiving the finished copies. Which I plan to be 60 days after the campaign is over.
  • The free audio and video downloads will be available by July 25th 2013.

I will need your shipping address as well as email address. All the correspondence I send out via email will come from my personal blogsite, www.anthonycolson.com.

Thank you!

 

The Impact

Publishing this book and getting it done in English will pave the way for the book to be distributed not only in the United States, but English speaking countries all over the world. This campaigns success will mean this book will not only be published and capable of impacting the hearts of the lost and broken, and downtrodden here, but also pave the way for the book’s translation into Spanish, Russian, Mandarin and a host of different languages. This book will open the hearts of people to Jesus, all over the world. However, it first has to be published.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please point people toward this campaign. Those you may know that need a message like this, point them this direction. Also, please use the IndieGoGo share tools to help spread the message!

Please point people toward this campaign. Those you may know that need a message like this, point them this direction. Also, please use the IndieGoGo share tools to help spread the message!

story:
GOAL:

  • To begin my first ever illustrated children's book featuring my science loving, tomboy character in an ongoing series of illustrated books, and get it published!

  • I'm writing and illustrating a full color, illustrated children's book about an inquisitive and intelligent young girl with a large imagination and a penchant for what might be considered "boyish" adventures, which will be part of a series of Charlotte Lively books. 

 

  • My book be self-published and approximately 30 pages of front to back full color illustrations. This will be BOOK 1 of my series, which will explore tales of fantasy, sci-fi and real life adventure!

 

  • The funds from this will give me the opportunity to take a few months off from freelance work and commissions to focus on the book, as well as publishing and distribution efforts.

 

  • The book will be available on digital PDF, eBook and in print.

 

  • For full info about the project, more images and updates beyond here, visit the official site: Charlottelively.com

 
 

The Charlotte Lively series is about a young girl who is interested in more than just fairytales and princess endings. She wants to explore the world and discover new adventures. Her imagination, unique view of the world and tomboyish nature will be a refreshing taste of life that young girls and boys will enjoy!  

SAMPLES & CONCEPTUAL DRAFTS FROM BOOK TO-BE:

 

 

WHY YOU SHOULD PARTICIPATE:

  • Backers of the project will not only give me the chance to focus on this book 100% but offer a unique experience for my family, friends and fans to be a part of the creation of Charlotte Lively and the books. 
  • Backers will not only recieve personalized, exclusive gifts as part of this project, but be able to view and participate in my weekly progress livecast, which I will offer after this project is funded. Dates and times will be announced here and on my site: CharlotteLively.com as well as my Facebook page so you can watch and interract with me on Google Hangout and YouTube live!
  • There, I will give you the latest updates on my book's progress, do some live illustration and take your questions!

 

ABOUT ME:

My name is Natasha andI'm a full time painter and illustrator for the last 9 years, living and working in Michigan. My art (as seen at Wescoatfineart.com) has been published in books and magazines and licensed on products in stores like Target, Bed Bath & Beyond, Barnes & Noble bookstores and Aaron Brothers. Because of my work, my art is taught in schools worldwide, and I've been able to participate in teaching art to children. I've also spoken at conferences like South by Southwest (SXSW) interactive, Blogworld & New Media expo and art workshops across the US.

This is the first book in a series that I've been planning and writing for the last 2 years. It's a passion project for me, and I'm looking forward to writing more to inspire young children to explore the arts and sciences. I write a blog, sharing advice with artists on business at Freshgloss.com and keep up with my community at my Facebook page and the official Charlotte Lively page.

 

NOTES ABOUT REWARDS:

  • All international orders (outside U.S.) that require shipping will be an additional $7 or $15 (depending on size of reward!)
  • To add another book to any tier, simply add $20 and be sure to include a note that you are buying another book and not just increasing donation amount.
  • All prints, books and art come signed. YES, even the postcards of course!

story:
Muchachos,

Andrea está pasando por un momento difícil y más allá del dinero que cada uno pueda entregar, estoy seguro que lo que más necesita es paz y tranquilidad, seguro que este es un gesto que ella no va a olvidar de nuestra parte como todo un equipo de Mentez y Paymentez.

story:
A Story Project by Nsikan Akpan

Outbreak. The word spawns chills and premonitions of hacking coughs, boils, oozing sores and death. Emerging viruses in the Middle East or East Asia, such as MERS and H7N9, are certainly frightening, but how does the coverage by outsider media compare to the sentiments of those reporting from ground zero of an epidemic?

This story concept spawned from a conversation that I once had about the taboos instilled against certain regions by global news coverage of infectious disease outbreaks.

Together, because this is an Open Project, we’ll investigate whether that’s true and much more. I will conduct multiple rounds of interviews to see how reporter perceptions’ evolve during an outbreak and after it has ‘resolved’ (either lost media steam or stopped spreading).

I will interview journalists and bloggers living near the epicenter of an outbreak and compare their views with those covering the situation from abroad. The current Ebola outbreak will be the ideal case study.

Image Credit: Produced by the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID), under a very-high magnification, this digitally-colorized scanning electron micrograph (SEM) depicts a single filamentous Ebola virus particle that had budded from the surface of a VERO cell of the African green monkey kidney epithelial cell line.

The fight against Ebola in West Africa, by European Commission DG ECHO Flickr Image: 4 months after the first case of Ebola was confirmed in Guinea, more than 1200 people have been infected across 3 West African countries. This biggest Ebola outbreak ever recorded requires an intensification of efforts to avoid it from spreading further and claiming many more lives. Photo credits: ©EC/ECHO/Jean-Louis Mosser

Sierra Leone, into the Ebola epicentre, by European Commission DG ECHO Flickr Image: As one of the Ebola epicentres, the district of Kailahun, in eastern Sierra Leone bordering Guinea, was put under quarantine at the beginning of August. ECHO expert Cyprien Fabre visited the distrtict which is home to the largest Ebola treatment and isolation centre ever erected. The 88 bed-facility set up by ECHO partner Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is full to capacity. In the same region, another ECHO partner, the Red Cross and its network of volunteers engage in another crucial task, namely social mobilisation, contact tracing and body management. 4 in 10 Ebola sufferers recover from the lethal disease and try to pick what's left of their lives in a region now cordoned off from the world. Photo credits: ©EC/ECHO/Cyprien Fabre

Nsikan Akpan is a science journalist based in Washington DC. He currently writes for NPR Global Health (goats and soda), but he has also contributed to Science Magazine, Scientific American, The Scientist Magazine, and Science News Magazine in the past. Once upon a time, he was a scientist who studied molecular medicine for stroke and the inner workings of parasites. He blogs at SciLogs.com and plays soccer whenever his ankles allow.

Nsikan Akpan On Twitter: 

@MoNscience
@nprGlobalHealth


What We Need & What You Get

I’m setting the bar at $1,000, but the proceeds will be divided evenly between three health organizations working in West Africa.

We’ll take submissions for possible organizations, and we’ll create an open survey so people can vote on where the money should go.

Every two weeks I’ll publish a story spotlighting a handful of different journalists. My prospective list is below. Feel free to suggest folks from across the globe.

This story will last as long as the outbreak (or longer if the people want me to continue).

    In North America

    Jennifer Yang, Toronto Star

    My story on latest Science study on 99 #Ebola genome sequences and what they reveal about the outbreak http://t.co/tGJu7nI7Ou

    — Jennifer Yang (@jyangstar) August 28, 2014

    Helen Branswell, Canadian Press

    Laurie Garrett, Senior fellow at Council on Foreign Relations

    Erika Check Hayden, Nature News

    Suzanne Locke, Vox.com

    In The Field

    Umaru Fofana, Sierra Leonean journalist, BBC/Reuters

    30-member contingent of British Army just landed #SierraLeone in response to #Ebola epidemic. They'll build a 700-bed treatment facility.

    — Umaru Fofana (@UmaruFofana) September 22, 2014

    Bate Felix Tabi Tabe, Correspondent, Reuters

    Tommy Trenchard, Journalist and photographer, NPR Global Health

    Jason Beaubien, reporter in Sierra Leone, NPR Global Health

    Clair MacDougall, Freelance

    Kerry Sheridan, AFP

    Frankie Taggart, AFP

    In Europe

    Fergus Walsh, BBC

    Ebola vaccine trial begins in Oxford: http://t.co/u0RIDU2LVA pic.twitter.com/kFnD6zZUTS

    — Fergus Walsh (@BBCFergusWalsh) September 17, 2014

    Helen Briggs, BBC

    Kai Kupferschmidt, Science Magazine

    Still searching for options; open to suggestions.

    In Asia

    Aldolfo Arranz, South China Morning Post

    Ebola outbreaks #infographic http://t.co/YNbgdGPCey #ebola #scmp

    — Adolfo Arranz (@adolfux) August 3, 2014

    Still searching for options; open to suggestions.


    Reach Goals

    SciLogs.com (managed by team member Paige Brown Jarreau) is also setting reach goals as follows:

    1. If we exceed our goal (>$1,000) then a portion of proceeds not to exceed $500 will go toward thanking our sponsor science magazine Spektrum der Wissenschaft, and thanking Nsikan for his time and volunteered reporting. 
    2. If we exceed $2000, funds not to exceed $500 will go toward paying for an extra month or more of in-depth regular Ebola reporting and Ebola media critiques at SciLogs.com, reported by invited guest freelance journalists and bloggers.


        The Story Depends on You

        Outbreak Abroad is the 2nd  installment of #OpenSciLogs, a new project at SciLogs.com designed to introduce crowd-funded, open, participatory science reporting to the science blogosphere and beyond.

        This #OpenSciLogs story project depends upon YOUR participation, and the participation of other science writers and readers. This story will feature regular blog updates at Nsikan's SciLogs.com blog, That's Basic Science, social media conversations (follow the hashtag #OpenSciLogs), and most importantly a public and editable Google Doc and interview files.

        Nsikan plans to help you participate in this story by providing you with all of his raw materials: transcripts of his interviews with journalists and editors, raw notes, raw data, etc. You can also make changes to the ongoing story in real time on this Google Doc. Nsikan also encourages you to provide comments on the story through the Google Doc and his blog post updates. And that's not all: all #OpenSciLogs content is published under a Creative Commons license, meaning you take and continue the story wherever you would like.

         

        OpenSciLogs by http://www.scilogs.com/ is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License. 

        Campaign Image Credit: CDC / Sally Ezra. This image captured in the West African country of Liberia, was created in 2014 during the Ebola hemorrhagic fever (Ebola HF) outbreak that affected the nations of Liberia, Sierra Leone, Guinea, and Nigeria.


        What is #OpenSciLogs

        Science blogs and other new digital and social media platforms for science writing are exploding while in-depth traditional media coverage of science, especially investigative science journalism, suffers. Unfortunately, many science bloggers and science writers for new digital media outlets go unpaid or underpaid. How can we help fund high quality science reporting “from the ground up,” in a way that prompts scientists and science writers in digital and social media environments - including the science blogosphere - to participate collectively in creating more in-depth science journalism across the web?

        This is where OpenSciLogs hopes to come in. The idea of OpenSciLogs is to combine crowd-funding with an “open notebook” and participatory approach to science writing, to produce in-depth science reporting from the ground up. By the ground up, we mean an ongoing science journalism process that starts in the science blogosphere, at SciLogs.com for now, and continues on to produce in-depth science storytelling in other nontraditional and traditional science media outlets across the web.

        In an effort to encourage open participation in a science storytelling process that transcends the individual science writer and the individual science blog, this project also embodies an “open notebook” approach to in-depth science reporting. The “open notebook” approach involves full disclosure and public publishing of raw story materials, a focus on science research published in open access mediums, and encouraging scientific story sources to provide their contact information for follow-up coverage of the story. In other words, each blogger leading an OpenSciLogs story project will both be joined by other science writers and readers in the investigation and writing of the story, and supply everything another science blogger, journalist or media outlet would need to fact-check and continue the story. 

        The conversation around each OpenSciLogs story project is meant to be open, and other journalists and bloggers should feel free to take the story to their own blogs, news sites, etc. By engaging readers and encouraging other science readers and writers to take the story in directions that interest them, OpenSciLogs’ bloggers will hopefully motivate others to participate actively in the story. Each #OpenSciLogs story project will be a living, breathing investigation into an important topic in science or science communication, published under a Creative Commons license. It’s in-depth science reporting by SciLogs.com, but more importantly, it’s in-depth science reporting by You.

        Outbreak Abroad is the second installment of #OpenSciLogs story projects.


        Other Ways You Can Help

        Just because you can’t contribute financially doesn’t mean you can’t help!

        We encourage all readers and writers interested in science to visit this Google Doc as the story gets underway, to leave comments or even help write the story yourself!

        Also, PLEASE spread the word about this campaign! Also follow us on Twitter @SciLogscom, and check out our hashtag #OpenSciLogs.
story_txt:
A Story Project by Nsikan Akpan
 
Outbreak. The word spawns chills and premonitions
of hacking coughs, boils, oozing sores
and death. Emerging viruses in the Middle East or East Asia,
such as MERS and H7N9, are certainly frightening, but how does the
coverage by outsider media compare to the sentiments of those reporting from
ground zero of an epidemic?
This story concept spawned from a conversation that I once
had about the taboos instilled against certain regions by global
news coverage of infectious disease outbreaks. 
Together, because this is an Open Project, we’ll investigate
whether that’s true and much more. I will conduct multiple rounds of interviews
to see how reporter perceptions’ evolve during an outbreak and after it has
‘resolved’ (either lost media steam or stopped spreading). 
I will interview journalists and bloggers living near the
epicenter of an outbreak and compare their views with those
covering the situation from abroad. The current
Ebola outbreak will be the ideal case study.




Image Credit: Produced by the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID), under a very-high magnification, this digitally-colorized scanning electron micrograph (SEM) depicts a single filamentous Ebola virus particle that had budded from the surface of a VERO cell of the African green monkey kidney epithelial cell line.




The fight against Ebola in West Africa, by European Commission DG ECHO Flickr Image: 4 months after the first case of Ebola was confirmed in Guinea, more than 1200
people have been infected across 3 West African countries. This biggest Ebola
outbreak ever recorded requires an intensification of efforts to avoid it from
spreading further and claiming many more lives. Photo credits:
©EC/ECHO/Jean-Louis Mosser

Sierra Leone, into the Ebola epicentre, by European Commission DG ECHO Flickr Image: As one of the Ebola epicentres, the district of Kailahun, in eastern Sierra Leone bordering Guinea, was put under quarantine at the beginning of August. ECHO expert Cyprien Fabre visited the distrtict which is home to the largest Ebola treatment and isolation centre ever erected. The 88 bed-facility set up by ECHO partner Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is full to capacity. In the same region, another ECHO partner, the Red Cross and its network of volunteers engage in another crucial task, namely social mobilisation, contact tracing and body management. 4 in 10 Ebola sufferers recover from the lethal disease and try to pick what's left of their lives in a region now cordoned off from the world. Photo credits: ©EC/ECHO/Cyprien Fabre

Nsikan Akpan is a science journalist based in Washington DC. He currently writes for NPR Global Health (goats and soda), but he has also contributed to Science Magazine, Scientific American, The Scientist Magazine, and Science News Magazine in the past. Once upon a time, he was a scientist who studied molecular medicine for stroke and the inner workings of parasites. He blogs at SciLogs.com and plays soccer whenever his ankles allow.


Nsikan Akpan On Twitter: 
@MoNscience@nprGlobalHealth


What We Need & What You Get 
I’m setting the bar at $1,000, but the
proceeds will be divided evenly between three health organizations working in
West Africa.
We’ll take submissions for possible
organizations, and we’ll create an open survey so people can vote on where the
money should go.
Every two weeks I’ll publish a story
spotlighting a handful of different journalists. My prospective list is below.
Feel free to suggest folks from across the globe.
This story will last as long as the
outbreak (or longer if the people want me to continue).

In North America
Jennifer
Yang, Toronto Star 
My story on latest Science study on 99 #Ebola genome sequences and what they reveal about the outbreak http://t.co/tGJu7nI7Ou— Jennifer Yang (@jyangstar) August 28, 2014

Helen
Branswell, Canadian Press
Laurie
Garrett, Senior fellow at Council on Foreign Relations
Erika
Check Hayden, Nature News

Suzanne
Locke, Vox.com


In The Field
Umaru
Fofana, Sierra Leonean journalist, BBC/Reuters 
30-member contingent of British Army just landed #SierraLeone in response to #Ebola epidemic. They'll build a 700-bed treatment facility.— Umaru Fofana (@UmaruFofana) September 22, 2014

Bate
Felix Tabi Tabe, Correspondent, Reuters
Tommy
Trenchard, Journalist and photographer, NPR Global Health
Jason
Beaubien, reporter in Sierra Leone, NPR Global Health
Clair
MacDougall, Freelance
Kerry
Sheridan, AFP
Frankie
Taggart, AFP
In Europe
Fergus
Walsh, BBC 
Ebola vaccine trial begins in Oxford: http://t.co/u0RIDU2LVA pic.twitter.com/kFnD6zZUTS— Fergus Walsh (@BBCFergusWalsh) September 17, 2014

Helen
Briggs, BBC 
Kai
Kupferschmidt, Science Magazine
Still
searching for options; open to suggestions.
In Asia
Aldolfo
Arranz, South China Morning Post 
Ebola outbreaks #infographic http://t.co/YNbgdGPCey #ebola #scmp— Adolfo Arranz (@adolfux) August 3, 2014

Still
searching for options; open to suggestions.




Reach Goals
SciLogs.com (managed by team member Paige Brown Jarreau) is also setting reach goals as follows:



If we exceed our goal (>$1,000) then a portion of proceeds not to exceed $500 will go toward thanking our sponsor science magazine Spektrum der Wissenschaft, and thanking Nsikan for his time and volunteered reporting. 

If we exceed $2000, funds not to exceed $500 will go toward paying for an extra month or more of in-depth regular Ebola reporting and Ebola media critiques at SciLogs.com, reported by invited guest freelance journalists and bloggers.




  
  

The Story Depends on You
Outbreak Abroad is the 2nd  installment of #OpenSciLogs, a new project at SciLogs.com designed to introduce crowd-funded, open, participatory science reporting to the science blogosphere and beyond.
This #OpenSciLogs story project depends upon YOUR participation, and the participation of other science writers and readers. This story will feature regular blog updates at Nsikan's SciLogs.com blog, That's Basic Science, social media conversations (follow the hashtag #OpenSciLogs), and most importantly a public and editable Google Doc and interview files.
Nsikan plans to help you participate in this story by providing you with all of his raw materials: transcripts of his interviews with journalists and editors, raw notes, raw data, etc. You can also make changes to the ongoing story in real time on this Google Doc. Nsikan also encourages you to provide comments on the story through the Google Doc and his blog post updates. And that's not all: all #OpenSciLogs content is published under a Creative Commons license, meaning you take and continue the story wherever you would like.

 
OpenSciLogs by http://www.scilogs.com/ is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License. 


Campaign Image Credit: CDC / Sally Ezra. This image captured in the West African country of Liberia, was created in 2014 during the Ebola hemorrhagic fever (Ebola HF) outbreak that affected the nations of Liberia, Sierra Leone, Guinea, and Nigeria.

What is #OpenSciLogs

Science blogs and other new digital and social media platforms for science writing are exploding while in-depth traditional media coverage of science, especially investigative science journalism, suffers. Unfortunately, many science bloggers and science writers for new digital media outlets go unpaid or underpaid. How can we help fund high quality science reporting “from the ground up,” in a way that prompts scientists and science writers in digital and social media environments - including the science blogosphere - to participate collectively in creating more in-depth science journalism across the web?
This is where OpenSciLogs hopes to come in. The idea of OpenSciLogs is to combine crowd-funding with an “open notebook” and participatory approach to science writing, to produce in-depth science reporting from the ground up. By the ground up, we mean an ongoing science journalism process that starts in the science blogosphere, at SciLogs.com for now, and continues on to produce in-depth science storytelling in other nontraditional and traditional science media outlets across the web.
In an effort to encourage open participation in a science storytelling process that transcends the individual science writer and the individual science blog, this project also embodies an “open notebook” approach to in-depth science reporting. The “open notebook” approach involves full disclosure and public publishing of raw story materials, a focus on science research published in open access mediums, and encouraging scientific story sources to provide their contact information for follow-up coverage of the story. In other words, each blogger leading an OpenSciLogs story project will both be joined by other science writers and readers in the investigation and writing of the story, and supply everything another science blogger, journalist or media outlet would need to fact-check and continue the story. 
The conversation around each OpenSciLogs story project is meant to be open, and other journalists and bloggers should feel free to take the story to their own blogs, news sites, etc. By engaging readers and encouraging other science readers and writers to take the story in directions that interest them, OpenSciLogs’ bloggers will hopefully motivate others to participate actively in the story. Each #OpenSciLogs story project will be a living, breathing investigation into an important topic in science or science communication, published under a Creative Commons license. It’s in-depth science reporting by SciLogs.com, but more importantly, it’s in-depth science reporting by You.
Outbreak Abroad is the second installment of #OpenSciLogs story projects.

Other Ways You Can Help
Just because you can’t contribute financially doesn’t mean you can’t help!
We encourage all readers and writers interested in science to visit this Google Doc as the story gets underway, to leave comments or even help write the story yourself!
Also, PLEASE spread the word about this campaign! Also follow us on Twitter @SciLogscom, and check out our hashtag #OpenSciLogs.

story:
Short Summary

Non-profit literary site www.CitajMe.com (Read Me) was launched in November 2013 with the goal to become central point for literary information in Croatia and surrounding region.

In short time website was recognized as a place where readers can:

  • find interesting book reviews for domestic and foreign book releases
  • get free books in our weekly giveaways
  • read interviews with local and foreign authors
  • find information about literary events
  • inform about the domestic and foreign book charts
  • find information about book releases
  • find literary trivia
  • participate in contests for new authors
  • find other exciting things from the world of books

Currently website is enjoyed in more than 40 countries worldwide and only last month it was opened more than 300,000 times.

For such amount of information daily maintenance imposed a need to expand team (currently 19 of people involved) who are all volunteers, paid only symbolically.

With your help

  • People who work in our team will be continuously paid at least with some fee
  • Website will be expanded with new features that will attract even larger audience
  • Maintenance costs will be covered and new hosting plan will be contracted

Highlights

Some highlights of the information you can find on our page:

  • Exclusive interviews with Deborah Harkness, Patrick deWitt, Ian Rankin, Chris Beckett, Lauren Beukes, Laurent Gounelle, Frederick W. Engdahl, Salomon Perel, Jean-Marie Blas de Roblès, Coen Simon, Alma Katsu, Erik Axl Sund, Peter Terrin, Rod Rees, Răzvan Radulescu, Margit Coates, Miloš Urban, ...
  • List of new releases with book cover and link with additional information
  • Birthdays of book authors from all around the planet for each calendar day
  • Book of the day
  • Book trivia
  • Book charts

What We Need & What You Get

We need at least $700 to cover the costs of manpower and technology for the next month:

  • Maintenance costs per month - $700
  • Personal wage per person per month – depends on your generosity

For your donations you will get:

  • $10 - Our gratitude for helping to move webpage one step closer to launching website www.citajme.com in larger scale
  • $25 - Your name will be printed in our "I Helped This Website" e-book, a tribute to everyone who contributed to success of this project. The book will be able to download at our website
  • $50 - Denis Vukosav (founder of www.citajme.com) will thank you by name in a video that will permanently be available to download on official webpage YouTube channel. There will be one video thanking everyone who donates at this level and we will also send you a copy of video
  • $100 - Your name will be displayed on www.citajme.com homepage labeled as a gold donor
  • $150 - If you are an author we will publish interview with you and present your generosity and literary works to the whole world

The Impact

We see our campaign as very valuable because as non-profit website our team is not under anyone's control or influence.

With your support we will be able to:

  • Expand our point of interest first on South Eastern Europe and Europe in general, and then worldwide
  • Provide information about less known editions
  • Promote self-published authors to larger audience

Risks & Challenges

Because of inability to pay staff almost all of people in our team had to search for other sources of income because they have to earn for a living. 

The challenge is to find an economy model that will not undermine the non-profit principles and yet secure a steady source of income

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute with money donations, please help us any of the other possible ways:

  • Spread the word around about our campaign and website
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools
  • Send us your suggestions how you can help our site to become better
  • Send us model of cooperation or support for which you would be interested

Thank you.

CitajMe.com team

story:
Paradise Lust? What?

Romance novels get a bad rap. Predictable plots, flat characters, words like "member" and "honeypot" (really). Paradise Lust is my small attempt to take that on, through a story with three-dimensional characters, a healthy dose of humor, zero instances of "heaving bosoms," and a firm belief that the romance reader is just as intelligent as any other reader. After all, we all like sex, right? 

Not this-->   

Though I've completed NaNoWriMo twice, Paradise Lust is the first novel I will publish, and my first romance. It has been a tremendously fun and educational undertaking, and something that I'd love to do again. Your contribution to this campaign will be a huge step toward making my debut novel a success.

Note: Jocelyn Kates is a nom de plume. "Real" me is a gal in Brooklyn who has spent ~7 years working in various aspects of the publishing industry and also happens to be a certified yoga instructor.

Where Do Contributions Go?

Though the manuscript itself is nearly complete, the last leg of the publication process entails a whole lot of stuff--and requires a bit of ca$h. Specifically:

  • Book cover and interior designs
  • Website design and domain cost
  • Formatting e-book files
  • Promotion and fees on digital publishing platforms (BN, Amazon, iTunes, Kobo, Smashwords)
  • Targeted ads and social media marketing campaigns
  • Business cards, posters, and other physical materials
  • Print or audio copies, if demand and funding is sufficient
  • Launch party and gifts for you generous folk!
In the case that Paradise Lust gets picked up by a publisher who foots the bill for some of the above, all remaining funds will go toward marketing and promotion...and maybe getting started on a sequel.

 <--Us at the launch party.


So What's This Book About?

It's about Bali, and meditation, and fickle tropical weather patterns, as well as proper alignment for standing half-moon pose and best practices for maintaining a laptop in humid weather. There's also sex, a bunch of sex. Because, well, it's a romance novel.

To find out more about the story, read an excerpt, and stay up-to-date on happenings on the blog, check out the Paradise Lust website.


Are There Perks for Contributions?

Yes. Yes, there are. Take a gander to the right.


Double Your Help by Sharing with a Friend!

Indiegogo has great tools for sharing. If you could pass this along and convince just one person in your network to contribute too, that would be enough to ensure that this campaign is a success!

story:
Update 4/2/2015:

The campaign is now successfully funded! A huge, appreciative robot hug goes out to all who supported it through financial contributions, social media shares and kind words of encouragement. I am so pleased and thrilled to be able to seize this dream opportunity to go to Odyssey Writing Workshop, and I couldn't have done it without all of you!

The campaign will still be active through Saturday, April 4 at 11:59 PT. Any additional funds raised will go toward feeding me while I am at the workshop. There are still several rad perks available, so tell your friends!


Short Summary

Before I introduce myself and explain the campaign, here are some pertinent links that will give you a better idea of what you're investing in, if you choose to contribute.

  • My Blog
  • The writing sample (a chapter from my novel in progress) that got me accepted to Odyssey Writing Workshop

Hi! I'm Leslie Starr O'Hara. I'm a mom and an audiobook producer living in the mountains of North Carolina, and I love to write science fiction and fantasy. A few years back I decided that writing was what I really wanted to do. I'd always been told I had a natural talent for it, and I would constantly make up stories in my head, and write them down just for fun. Throughout my life, writing has been creatively fulfilling for me. But I wanted and needed to be a better writer. It was not enough just to write. I had to write stories that people would fall in love with, that would keep them hooked until the very last page. And I didn't know how to do that.

So I dedicated a lot of focus and time and energy to learning how to do it. I have worked really hard over the past few years to improve my writing skills, through study of story-craft, in addition to lots of writing, revising, writing, revising and more writing. Last year, I completed NaNoWriMo (National Novel Writer's Month) for the first time. Basically that means that I wrote 50,000 words in 30 days towards the completion of a novel. I got the novel about halfway done during NaNo (it's a long novel told in three separate points of view) and that really contributed to my growth as a writer. I feel like I've made immense strides, and sort of like I'm tottering on the brink of a major epiphany, where all the bits and pieces I've learned and practiced fall into place and my fiction takes off like a rocket.

Earlier this year, I applied to Odyssey Writing Workshop, one of the most highly regarded workshops in the world for writers of science fiction, fantasy and horror. The workshop is a six-week, intensive residential program held annually at Saint Anselm College in New Hampshire, and taught by Jeanne Cavelos, a former editor with decades of experience in helping authors improve their work.

I really did not expect to get in, because I knew that the competition was stiff, and that there would be a lot of really talented writers applying. So it came as a pleasant (amazing, spine-tingling, heart-thumping) surprise when, on February 28, I received an acceptance letter from the workshop! I feel so honored and humbled to be included in this year's group of 16 up and coming speculative fiction writers at Odyssey, and to learn from some truly great writers, like Kij Johnson and Alex Hughes. This is the opportunity of a lifetime for me. 

But I need help to get there. The workshop is not cheap, but it is, in my opinion, priced far below the immense value I will receive from it. Bottom line is, I do not have the money immediately at my disposal to pay for my travel to and attendance at the workshop. So I hope you'll consider pitching in a few bucks to help me achieve my goal. In return, I'm offering some pretty cool perks to sweeten the deal. Read on to learn more!


Cost Breakdown

Here's how the $3500 breaks down:

  • $2181 for tuition and required text
  • $864 for on-campus lodging
  • $455 for round-trip air travel to the workshop from Asheville, NC (that was the lowest price when I checked multiple sites on March 3.)

There are a few scholarships available, as well, but I have no guarantee of getting them, and won't know if I've received one until very shortly before the final tuition and housing payments are due. So it's definitely not something I can rely on.

If the entire goal is not reached, the funds raised will still be used to help send me to Odyssey. I do not know how I would come up with the remaining funds, but if it comes to that, I will find a way or conjure one. I WILL go to Odyssey. This is way too important to let little setbacks get in the way.

On the other hand, if the campaign exceeds its goal, the excess funds will be used to pay for my nutritional sustenance while I am at Odyssey and/or missed income while I am away.


Sweet Perks


There ain't no such thing as a free lunch, and this is equally true for science fiction writers as for diners at your local Chinese buffet. Therefore, I have brainstormed some really cool rewards for those who contribute to this campaign and help me get to Odyssey! 

The perks include:

  • Digital copies of all the stories I write while at Odyssey (should be 5 or 6 of them)
  • Colorful, vintage science fiction posters (reproductions of old magazine covers and movie promos) from my personal collection. The four posters are shown above.
  • Audiobook narration and production services (This is the skillset I possess that currently feeds me. Check out a sample of my narration skillz here.)
  • A uniquely mindcrafted, completely fabricated 500 word description of you that you can use as a bio on social media sites. Provide me a picture of yourself and I will use my powers of perception and humor to craft a unique and original blurb. You can even request it to be written in the exaggerated style of your favorite writer or genre!
  • Name a character in one of my stories. You can name him or her after yourself, after a loved one as a gift, or make up some completely ridiculous and hard-to-pronounce name just to mess with me. Your choice!
  • There are more great perks. Take a look to the right of this page to see them all.

Update 3/25/2015:  NEW PERK!!!

My good friends at Sacred Lotus Tattoo in Asheville, NC (where I live) have donated a $100 gift certificate toward a tattoo by Jessica Guillory (see her portfolio here) as a perk for my campaign! Bonus: The tattoo doesn't have to be a picture of me. Thanks, guys!!


The Impact

Stories are a universally accepted currency. We are culturally and evolutionarily predisposed to give and receive them. Babies, businessmen and bikers all need stories in the same way that a house needs windows. We may survive without them, but our existence will be dark and isolated. They form the majority of our personal identities, and they help us relate to and empathize with others. They inspire, inform and enlighten us. Stories help us process difficult emotions- grief, anger, desperation. And they make us relax, laugh and love. 

We all need stories. And not only ordinary stories about ordinary people who face struggles in their ordinary lives. We also need weird stories about people, androids, wizards and aliens who face fantastical struggles in the future, or in space, or in a mystical realm, or in some kind of crazy time rift. With pirates. People like me need stories like that to nourish our minds and to satiate our freakish little hearts. We need speculative fiction.

Of course, there are numerous very talented science fiction and fantasy writers out there already, and you should read their work! I'm not saying that we are dealing with a dearth of good speculative fiction. I'm saying that we lack stories that are uniquely Starr-ish. And that's because my fiction has been incubating in this dragon's egg for a while, soaking up nutrients from all my study and practice. But it's time for that dragon to break the eggshell and emerge. It's time for it to stretch its scaly wings and soar! And I believe Odyssey is the place for that to occur. Of course, even then, it will only be a baby dragon, and will still require my lifelong commitment and care to help it grow into the fearsomely beautiful beast it might become. As chief dragon hostler (dragstler?), I am in this for the long haul.


Risks & Challenges

Like any great venture, there are some very real challenges that come along with this opportunity. They are:
  • I will be away from my family, and specifically my nine-year-old, for six weeks. I have never been away from my child for that long, and it will be emotionally hard for me, but even more so for her. Additionally, I will not be at home during the summer months to provide care for her while her dad is at work full-time. Fortunately, my family believes in me and is being amazingly supportive. My husband is confident that we can make it work with the help of grandparents and day camps, and my daughter says that she is really proud of me and wants me to go more than she wants me to stay.
  • The workshop is going to be extremely intensive, and at times, grueling. I know this. In addition to writing one short story a week (if you've ever written a short story, and you're not a time jumper, you probably know that this in itself is quite a feat), I will also be reading and critiquing the stories all the other students turn in, and doing class readings, discussions and writing exercises. As one Odyssey alumnus wrote: "The experience was harrowing and thrilling all at once—the intensive workshop combined with mind-bending lectures on craft meant I fell asleep every night with my head spinning. Sometimes I cried. Sometimes I wanted to go home. Sometimes I thought, This is the most fun I’ve ever had." I am prepared for this. I know it will be hard, but I can handle it. I am, after all, the mother of a nine-year-old.


Other Ways You Can Help

Not ready to make a contribution to the campaign, and wondering if there are other ways you can show your support? There are! You can:

  • Tell your friends! Share the campaign on Facebook, Twitter, or your social media platform of choice.
  • If you have a blog or a podcast, consider interviewing me before and after the workshop!
story_txt:
Update 4/2/2015: 

The campaign is now successfully funded! A huge, appreciative robot hug goes out to all who supported it through financial contributions, social media shares and kind words of encouragement. I am so pleased and thrilled to be able to seize this dream opportunity to go to Odyssey Writing Workshop, and I couldn't have done it without all of you! 
The campaign will still be active through Saturday, April 4 at 11:59 PT. Any additional funds raised will go toward feeding me while I am at the workshop. There are still several rad perks available, so tell your friends! 

Short Summary
Before I introduce myself and explain the campaign, here are some pertinent links that will give you a better idea of what you're investing in, if you choose to contribute.

My Blog

The writing sample (a chapter from my novel in progress) that got me accepted to Odyssey Writing Workshop

Hi! I'm Leslie Starr O'Hara. I'm a mom and an audiobook producer living in the mountains of North Carolina, and I love to write science fiction and fantasy. A few years back I decided that writing was what I really wanted to do. I'd always been told I had a natural talent for it, and I would constantly make up stories in my head, and write them down just for fun. Throughout my life, writing has been creatively fulfilling for me. But I wanted and needed to be a better writer. It was not enough just to write. I had to write stories that people would fall in love with, that would keep them hooked until the very last page. And I didn't know how to do that.
So I dedicated a lot of focus and time and energy to learning how to do it. I have worked really hard over the past few years to improve my writing skills, through study of story-craft, in addition to lots of writing, revising, writing, revising and more writing. Last year, I completed NaNoWriMo (National Novel Writer's Month) for the first time. Basically that means that I wrote 50,000 words in 30 days towards the completion of a novel. I got the novel about halfway done during NaNo (it's a long novel told in three separate points of view) and that really contributed to my growth as a writer. I feel like I've made immense strides, and sort of like I'm tottering on the brink of a major epiphany, where all the bits and pieces I've learned and practiced fall into place and my fiction takes off like a rocket.


Earlier this year, I applied to Odyssey Writing Workshop, one of the most highly regarded workshops in the world for writers of science fiction, fantasy and horror. The workshop is a six-week, intensive residential program held annually at Saint Anselm College in New Hampshire, and taught by Jeanne Cavelos, a former editor with decades of experience in helping authors improve their work. 
I really did not expect to get in, because I knew that the competition was stiff, and that there would be a lot of really talented writers applying. So it came as a pleasant (amazing, spine-tingling, heart-thumping) surprise when, on February 28, I received an acceptance letter from the workshop! I feel so honored and humbled to be included in this year's group of 16 up and coming speculative fiction writers at Odyssey, and to learn from some truly great writers, like Kij Johnson and Alex Hughes. This is the opportunity of a lifetime for me. 
But I need help to get there. The workshop is not cheap, but it is, in my opinion, priced far below the immense value I will receive from it. Bottom line is, I do not have the money immediately at my disposal to pay for my travel to and attendance at the workshop. So I hope you'll consider pitching in a few bucks to help me achieve my goal. In return, I'm offering some pretty cool perks to sweeten the deal. Read on to learn more!

  Cost Breakdown 
 Here's how the $3500 breaks down:

$2181 for tuition and required text
$864 for on-campus lodging
$455 for round-trip air travel to the workshop from Asheville, NC (that was the lowest price when I checked multiple sites on March 3.)

There are a few scholarships available, as well, but I have no guarantee of getting them, and won't know if I've received one until very shortly before the final tuition and housing payments are due. So it's definitely not something I can rely on. 


If the entire goal is not reached, the funds raised will still be used to help send me to Odyssey. I do not know how I would come up with the remaining funds, but if it comes to that, I will find a way or conjure one. I WILL go to Odyssey. This is way too important to let little setbacks get in the way.On the other hand, if the campaign exceeds its goal, the excess funds will be used to pay for my nutritional sustenance while I am at Odyssey and/or missed income while I am away.

Sweet Perks




There ain't no such thing as a free lunch, and this is equally true for science fiction writers as for diners at your local Chinese buffet. Therefore, I have brainstormed some really cool rewards for those who contribute to this campaign and help me get to Odyssey! 
The perks include:

Digital copies of all the stories I write while at Odyssey (should be 5 or 6 of them)
Colorful, vintage science fiction posters (reproductions of old magazine covers and movie promos) from my personal collection. The four posters are shown above.
Audiobook narration and production services (This is the skillset I possess that currently feeds me. Check out a sample of my narration skillz here.)
A uniquely mindcrafted, completely fabricated 500 word description of you that you can use as a bio on social media sites. Provide me a picture of yourself and I will use my powers of perception and humor to craft a unique and original blurb. You can even request it to be written in the exaggerated style of your favorite writer or genre!
Name a character in one of my stories. You can name him or her after yourself, after a loved one as a gift, or make up some completely ridiculous and hard-to-pronounce name just to mess with me. Your choice!
There are more great perks. Take a look to the right of this page to see them all.

Update 3/25/2015:  NEW PERK!!!
My good friends at Sacred Lotus Tattoo in Asheville, NC (where I live) have donated a $100 gift certificate toward a tattoo by Jessica Guillory (see her portfolio here) as a perk for my campaign! Bonus: The tattoo doesn't have to be a picture of me. Thanks, guys!!






The ImpactStories are a universally accepted currency. We are culturally and evolutionarily predisposed to give and receive them. Babies, businessmen and bikers all need stories in the same way that a house needs windows. We may survive without them, but our existence will be dark and isolated. They form the majority of our personal identities, and they help us relate to and empathize with others. They inspire, inform and enlighten us. Stories help us process difficult emotions- grief, anger, desperation. And they make us relax, laugh and love.  We all need stories. And not only ordinary stories about ordinary people who face struggles in their ordinary lives. We also need weird stories about people, androids, wizards and aliens who face fantastical struggles in the future, or in space, or in a mystical realm, or in some kind of crazy time rift. With pirates. People like me need stories like that to nourish our minds and to satiate our freakish little hearts. We need speculative fiction.Of course, there are numerous very talented science fiction and fantasy writers out there already, and you should read their work! I'm not saying that we are dealing with a dearth of good speculative fiction. I'm saying that we lack stories that are uniquely Starr-ish. And that's because my fiction has been incubating in this dragon's egg for a while, soaking up nutrients from all my study and practice. But it's time for that dragon to break the eggshell and emerge. It's time for it to stretch its scaly wings and soar! And I believe Odyssey is the place for that to occur. Of course, even then, it will only be a baby dragon, and will still require my lifelong commitment and care to help it grow into the fearsomely beautiful beast it might become. As chief dragon hostler (dragstler?), I am in this for the long haul.


  Risks & ChallengesLike any great venture, there are some very real challenges that come along with this opportunity. They are:
I will be away from my family, and specifically my nine-year-old, for six weeks. I have never been away from my child for that long, and it will be emotionally hard for me, but even more so for her. Additionally, I will not be at home during the summer months to provide care for her while her dad is at work full-time. Fortunately, my family believes in me and is being amazingly supportive. My husband is confident that we can make it work with the help of grandparents and day camps, and my daughter says that she is really proud of me and wants me to go more than she wants me to stay.
The workshop is going to be extremely intensive, and at times, grueling. I know this. In addition to writing one short story a week (if you've ever written a short story, and you're not a time jumper, you probably know that this in itself is quite a feat), I will also be reading and critiquing the stories all the other students turn in, and doing class readings, discussions and writing exercises. As one Odyssey alumnus wrote: "The experience was harrowing and thrilling all at once—the intensive
workshop combined with mind-bending lectures on craft meant I fell asleep every
night with my head spinning. Sometimes I cried. Sometimes I wanted to go home.
Sometimes I thought, This is the most fun
I’ve ever had." I am prepared for this. I know it will be hard, but I can handle it. I am, after all, the mother of a nine-year-old.




  Other Ways You Can Help
Not ready to make a contribution to the campaign, and wondering if there are other ways you can show your support? There are! You can:

Tell your friends! Share the campaign on Facebook, Twitter, or your social media platform of choice. 

If you have a blog or a podcast, consider interviewing me before and after the workshop!

story:
Short Summary

I am needing help distributing my second book, Lucy and The New Baby! Also, I would like to have the funding to turn BOTH my Lucy books into an animated series! Lots of time and money go into spreading the word about my book.

About Me:

My name is Kim Yannayon and I am the author of Lucy's Big Mess & Lucy and The New Baby.  I have always had a passion for reading and writing.  I am a wife, mother, coffee lover, and pet enthusiast.  

My goal is write children's books that will instill manners, values, and messages of positive reinforcement that today's generation is missing. I would also, like to turn my books into an animated series.

With your help, we can give kids a story to read that actually teaches them something!


What We Need & What You Get

Here is the break down.....

  • $5.00 - You get a personalized Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, and LinkedIn Thank you!
  • $10.00 - You get the above, as well as, a personalized thank you card.
  • $15.00 - You will receive the social media thank you and a signed copy of my first book, Lucy's Big Mess.
  • $25.00 - You will receive the social media thank you and a little goody bag filled with pencils, pens, book mark, and a few other things.
  • $50.00 - You will receive the social media thank you, a signed copy of my first book, Lucy's Big Mess, and the goody bag.
  • $100.00 - You will receive the social media thank you, a signed copy of first book, goody bag, and a coffee mug.
  • $150.00 - You will receive the social media thank you, a signed copy of first book, goody bag,  a signed 3-D copy, and a pre-released, signed copy of Lucy and The New Baby!
  • $200.00 - You will receive the social media thank you, a signed copy of the first book and the 3-D copy, a pre-release signed copy of the second book, Lucy and The New Baby, the goody bag, and the coffee cup.
  • $500.00 - You will receive it all! The social media THANK YOU!, the signed paperback copy and 3-D copy of the first book, a signed pre-released copy of the second book, the goody bag, the coffee cup, and a Lucy's Big Mess Blanket!

What does the money pay for?

  1. Hire someone to animate my books into a working series to pitch for networks
  2. Order enough books to sell and distribute! (This is a biggie)
  3. Pay for advertising costs and fees.
  4. Schedule and reserve tables at stores, fairs, and other places for book signing events.
  5. Pay for travel expenses and food costs.
  6. I will be able to maintain the websites and social pages.

story:
Who Are You?

It may not seem like much of a question, but as I've learned over the course my own life, it is in fact, one of the most fundamental questions one can ask themselves.
My name is Karry L. Dayton, I am writer of sorts, a philosopher as well and very, very opinionated. I published a fictional work of philosophy called Saint Horz: The Stone Saint two years ago, for those that had read it, it seems well received. Only, it was complex and required a very specific starting point.
The Constitution for a Fifth Grader starts from the beginning. It starts with defining the concept of "You" and from there travels down the rabbit hole of philosophy to illuminate how exactly this intrinsic definition of self was lost and later overthrown by the lie of self-sacrifice.

Why Constitution for a Fifth Grader?

The idea of a book being directed at a younger crowd, I have to give credit to Ludwig Von Mises in his work called Socialism. He mentions that he does not expect to have the ability to influence the current intellectuals that dominate thought, but in his optimism, he reminds us that there is always a new generation coming up. Then there were things like; Judge Andrew Napolitano's work on Woodrow Wilson and Theodore Roosevelt. In that book he suggests that Wilson instituted the public school system not simply as a method of educating children, for there were already schools, but as a way to indoctrinate them to a social view outside their current parent controlled idealism; specifically in opposition to Catholicism. Then there are all the objective views that we see often: Are you Smarter than a Fifth Grader for example. And then, as I was coming up with the name of this work, I got an email from the White House Press Corps, implying that the President wants to thank his fifth grader teacher for her help in shaping the man he had become. It was settled then: Fifth Grade is the moment when the heavy hand of socialism (collectivism) starts to really take hold and that point in our revolution that we must begin the conversation.

Why this book?

This book begins as follows:
This book is intentionally subversion. It is rebellion. It is revolt. You have been living in absence of revolution.
It is true. You and I so long ago, by our births, have been living under a socialism so well ingrained so deeply part of our psyche, that we were incapable of even noticing that we were living by it. I remember reading The Fountainhead by Ayn Rand and loving the book, but not really understanding Howard Roark's character. He seemed so distant, so, as the ugly truth of socialism requires, selfish and self absorbed. Yet, I sensed, that something about his character was absolutely natural and correct. It wasn't until I read a lot more and could break the paradigm established by public schools and the media, that I was able to see that Howard wasn't the odd ball, but it was the system he had to work under that was utterly broken. He saw it was broken, thus, refusing to even acknowledge or comply; he did things by is own nature. He was the first fictional character I'd ever read whom lived by his own motive power.

Perks

As a thank you for helping my launch this title, I will be including a few perks, based on the amount of the contribution. These are listed in the same order as the perk list to the right:
  • One signed copy of Constitution For A Fifth Grader
  • One signed copy of Constitution For A Fifth Grader and One copy of Lysander Spooner's No Treason: The Constitution of no Authority. These are a matched set, with matching covers and will be numbered. There will only be 120 numbered sets, ever printed.
  • Two copies of each title - With this second copy I will send it with your personal note to whom ever you want me to send it too, if you so choose.
  • Two signed copies, plus the following:
    • One Sons of Liberty Rebellious Stripes sticker - This is the nine vertical stripes.
    • One Pocket Constitution and Declaration of Independence
    • One set of Parchments for framing that includes: The Declaration of Independence, the US Constitution, The Bill of Rights, and the Gettysburg Address
    • One US Flag pen - so that you can symbolically sign the Declaration of Independence as a reminder to others, that it informs those institutions that they do not own us.

Thank you

As one final note. I'm an Objectivist, a Capitalist, and expect to only do business with others based on the voluntary exchange of goods or service. Because of this, I'm stating simply, do not buy this book to 'help' me. Buy it because you want it, because you have a desire to look beyond the collective, beyond the socialism both large and small. That you want something; sense that something is fundamentally wrong with the current state of affairs and that you want information, greedily. You hunger and want to know the how and the why.

story:
Long story short:

  • My name is Stephan Urbach. You may know me as an activist for free communication. I once was part of the group Telecomix.
  • Telecomix was an international group of activists working for free communication. During the green revolution (known as „Arab Spring“) we were working with people on the ground in Egypt. When Mubarak shut down the internet, we deployed modem landlines and faxed the modem numbers to Egypt. People used them to write Emails, blogposts and upload small pictures form Tahrir.
  • When the protests started in Syria, we were working with Syrians to help them to get pictures and videos out of the country without getting caught by the Syrian intelligence services or the police.
  • We made friends with people in Syria. Some of them got killed by the Assad regime. We had hard times and struggled - as individuals and as a group.
  • I have held lectures about our work all over the world - from FSCONS in Sweden to Free Connected Minds in Beirut. From lectures in Harvard and Yale to DOKU:TECH in Prizren.
  • Together with Ingo Petz I wrote a book about the events and my life as an activist. It has, in fact, been published in German by a large publisher. You can get it in German on Amazon, as an import in any bookstore or in my own shop. It has received great reviews in the media.
  • Now I want the whole world to know my story. That's why I want it to be translated into English.
  • There are publishers interested in bringing the book to the English speaking markets. They, however, fear the costs of a translation. I have regained the rights for a translation into English from my German Publisher.
  • I'm not afraid of the costs - because I have you!

What you give and what you get:

  • If the campaign hits €3800 I will be able to pay for the translation. The translation will be made by a professional translator - Anwen Roberts. You do not need to buy a pig in a poke - we already translated the first chapter and you can read it here. The cover layout of the book is designed by a friend of mine (Christopher of Chriss Cross Media) for a very cheap price. All people involved in this project get paid - because no one should work for free (except me). I have to pay for the perks on my own.
  • Atari Teenage Riot has written an exclusive Soundtrack for the book! ATR is going to release it for free after the campaign hit it’s goal as they just stated on their website.
  • €1500 Euros more - and I can not only pay for the perks but I can also deliver a hardcover edition. Every Euro more helps to bring an even shinier edition to life.
  • All editions produced by this campaign are limited. They will not be produced like this afterwards. In fact, I have no idea what will happen after the campaign is done and the book is delivered.

After the money kicked in (Chances & Risks):

I will deliver.

  • It is hard to bring a book to life. It is even harder to get it translated in a proper way. With this campaign you can show that international publication of books in high quality on your own is doable without exploiting people working on it. I know the prices I have to pay are cheap - the people supporting me in this project do it because they do believe the same way as I do in this project.
  • If the goal is NOT reached I will find other sources to fund it. I am willing to sell my soul to bring this translation to life. It just will need a longer time to achieve.
  • By supporting this project you will help me tell this important story to the world. You will also show that it is possible to independently translate and publish a book.

You can help!

  • Please let your english speaking community know about my project. Help me spread it all over the interwebz. Tell your friends, family and co-workers. Help me to reach out. Indiegogo provides a tool to help you doing so.
  • There are Shirts, Hoodies and Zippers available - as they are not perkable for me, you can get them here.

Reviews of the German book .NEUSTART

Here are some reviews form German speaking sites:

  • The German television station ARD gave the book 5 out of 6 stars and put it onto the list of the 13 most important books of the Frankfurt Book Fair.
  • "'.REBOOT' is an uncontrolledly honest book telling about a life dealing with nothing and everything but actual dealing with one thing: to understand this world, change it and not collapsing doing so." (politik-digital.de)
  • "His (Urbach's) book is not another netphilosophical sorry effort which you read and take some nice ideas from and put in the shelf. His book is unperfected, emotional, lacks from emotional detachment. It deeply moves. Thanks." (Publikumsbeschimpfung)
  • "'.REBOOT" is an extraordinary intensive book, deeply moving and frightening at the same time showing that its worthwhile to commit to others and that there is no shame to admit your flaws." (Hanauer Bote)
  • 7 Reviews on Amazon - all with 5 stars.
